bibl.title: Letter from Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon to Philip Showalter Hench, April 26, 1948

div1.p: Rodriguez Leon congratulates Hench on his campaign to preserve Building No. 1. She mentions that Finlay supporters were disturbed by Truman's speech.

div1.head: Letter from Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon to Philip Showalter Hench, April 26, 1948
div1.opener:
RUSTON ACADEMY
G Y QUINTA, VEDADO
HABANA, CUBA
April 26, 1948.
BOARD OF ADVISORS
PRESIDENT:
RAFAEL PALACIOS
SECRETARY:
MARIO NÚÑEZ MESA
MEMBERS:
WILLIAM P. FIELD
BURKE HEDGES
JOHN Z. HORTER
TEODORO JOHNSON
F. ADAIR MONROE
FREDERICK A. MORRIS
PHILIP ROSENBERG
HERMINIO PORTEL VILÁ
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minn. U.S.A.
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
My warmest thanks for the excellent photostatic
copies you have made of my father's papers. A very good
job; and, as a matter of fact, many of them are far more
legible in the copy you have made than they were in the
original. I am indeed very glad to have them.

Of the different methods if you suggest for re-
turning the original data I believe the best route will be
Dr. Nogueira, if he is willing to take the trouble. I don't
know him personally but he has made a very good reputation
for himself, and I consider him incapable of tampering with
scientific materials of any kind. Nevertheless, to avoid
possible use of these facts, in a way that would be untrue
or biased (I think the time is not yet ripe for cool appre-
ciation of the relative values by my fellow countrymen) it
would be indeed advisable to have the package sealed as you
suggested. Wouldn't that make some trouble for Nogueira with
the U.S. or Cuban customs officials? I am planning to see or
speak to him over the telephone in the next few days, and I
shall get his consent before he leaves Havana. As soon as I
do, I shall follow this up with a note to let you know what
he says about it. Otherwise, registered air mail, seems safe
enough at present, though of course terribly expensive.

You need not thank me for lending you the papers.
They are in good hands, and if you eventually see that the
official Army records are completed and that the files per-
taining to my father are duely corrected I shall feel amply
rewarded for any help I may have given you in clearing up
some of the dark spots of the experiments. Also that the facts
be brought to the attention of Generals Kean, Truby and Reed.

As to the letter from my father to Hemmeter, I have
gone through those papers that I had with me the day of your
visit. As far as I can see, the only letter of which I have
a copy is - as you thought - dated February 2, 1913. It seems
to me that Hemmeter's reply actually answers this letter, line
by line. There must be some mistake in quoting the dates. If you
want a copy of that I can send it to you. When I check the prin-
ted matter I gave you, to see if I have reprints so you can
keep the copies xx you now have, I shall search again, but
I believe the contents of the letters make sense as they are,
though the dates do not agree.

RUSTON ACADEMY
G Y QUINTA, VEDADO
HABANA, CUBA

BOARD OF ADVISORS
PRESIDENT:
RAFAEL PALACIOS
SECRETARY:
MARIO NÚÑEZ MESA
MEMBERS:
WILLIAM P. FIELD
BURKE HEDGES
JOHN Z. HORTER
TEODORO JOHNSON
F. ADAIR MONROE
FREDERICK A. MORRIS
PHILIP ROSENBERG
HERMINIO PORTEL VILÁ

My congratulations of the success of your campaign
for the preservation of the remains of Camp Lazear. I hadn't
heard of it. I am afraid some ill feeling has been aroused
lately among the Finlay-fanatics by the fact that President
Truman, in his speech at the celebration of the 50th. anniver-
sary of the Joint Resolution, mentioned Reed, Gorgas and my
father and left out Finlay entirely. Of course he referred to
the cooperation between Americans and Cubans, but it was immediat
diately picked up here and taken as a deliberate slight to
Dr. Finlay.

I would give a great deal to hear your “oration” at
the International Congress on Tropical Medicine. Please let
me at least read a copy of both that and your speech at the
unveiling of Reed's bust. My father always admired Dr. Reed
inmensely, and all the petty jealousies and envy of Carroll
never made him change his regard for him. Re-reading the
handwritten letter you copied I find considerable
warmth in his words and the dignified southern courtesy I
often heard my father comment on. I don't think there can
be any doubt as to my father being “in” on the experiments,
after seeing the personal letters, wherefor which Dr. Reed gradually
makes him responsabile for most of the preliminary arrange-
ments, even before the Y.F. Commission began working together.

Please remember to send me clippings or copies of
your speeches at the Washington Congress. In the next few days
I shall get in touch with Dr. Nogueira and will let you know
how things stand. There is another plan also: a very intimate
friend of my family is coming down in June to visit me (for
several months) She is a retired nurse and lives at present
in Pleasantville, N.Y. I don't know how far that is from the
city but it might be possible for her to contact you during
your visit to New York in the latter part of May. Well we can
arrange for this in case Dr. N. proves difficult to count upon.

Again my thanks for the fine copies. and my best
regards to your charming wife.
